verses.text: Now Naaman, commander of the army of the king of Aram, was a great man before his master and highly respected, because by him the LORD had given victory to Aram. He was a mighty man of valor, but a leper.
verses.comment: Maintained 'leper' for accuracy; modern translation keeps 'leprosy', though original term may include various skin diseases.

verses.text: And the Arameans had gone out in bands and had captured from the land of Israel a young girl, who served Naaman’s wife.
verses.comment: Kept 'young girl' close to original; the word can mean 'little girl'.

verses.text: She said to her mistress, 'If only my master were with the prophet who is in Samaria! Then he would cure him of his leprosy.'
verses.comment: Kept the wishful tone as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Naaman went in and told his master, saying, 'This is what the girl from the land of Israel said.'
Then the king of Aram said, 'Go now, and I will send a letter to the king of Israel.' So he went, taking with him ten talents of silver, six thousand shekels of gold, and ten changes of clothes.
verses.comment: Kept units of measure; talent = about 75 lbs., shekel ≈ 0.4 oz.

verses.text: And he brought the letter to the king of Israel, which read: 'Now when this letter reaches you, know that I have sent Naaman my servant to you, that you may cure him of his leprosy.'

When the king of Israel read the letter, he tore his clothes and said, 'Am I God, to kill and make alive, that this man sends me a man to cure him of his leprosy? Only consider, and see how he seeks a quarrel with me.'
verses.comment: Maintained idiomatic 'tear his clothes' (sign of distress in Hebrew culture).

verses.text: And when Elisha, the man of God, heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent word to the king, saying, 'Why have you torn your clothes? Let him come to me, and he will know that there is a prophet in Israel.'
So Naaman came with his horses and chariots and stood at the door of Elisha’s house.
And Elisha sent a messenger out to him, saying, 'Go and wash seven times in the Jordan, and your flesh will be restored, and you will be clean.'
verses.comment: Kept the command direct and literal; 'wash' meaning 'bathe'.

verses.text: But Naaman became angry and went away, saying, 'Look, I thought he would surely come out to me, stand and call on the name of the LORD his God, wave his hand over the place, and cure the leprosy.'
verses.comment: Preserved Naaman's expectations and disappointment.

verses.text: 'Are not Abana and Pharpar, the rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? Could I not wash in them and be clean?' So he turned and went away in a rage.
verses.comment: Kept river names as transliterated commonly (Abanah/Abana and Pharpar).

verses.text: But his servants came near and spoke to him, saying, 'My father, if the prophet had told you to do something great, would you not have done it? How much more, then, when he says to you,
verses.comment: 'My father' is an honorific, not literal.

verses.text: So he went down and dipped himself seven times in the Jordan, according to the word of the man of God, and his flesh was restored like the flesh of a young boy, and he was clean.
verses.comment: Kept literal description of restored flesh.

verses.text: Then he returned to the man of God, with all his attendants, and came and stood before him and said, 'Now I know that there is no God in all the earth except in Israel. Please accept a gift from your servant.'
verses.comment: 'gift' (Hebrew: blessing).

verses.text: But he said, 'As surely as the LORD lives, whom I serve, I will not accept anything.' And even though he urged him, Elisha refused.
verses.comment: 'whom I serve' literal, 'stand before'.

verses.text: Then Naaman said, 'If you won’t accept, let me, your servant, be given as much earth as two mules can carry, for your servant will no longer offer burnt offerings or sacrifices to other gods, but only to the LORD.'
verses.comment: Earth requests for worship; closely translated.

verses.text: 'But in this matter, may the LORD pardon your servant: When my master goes into the house of Rimmon to worship there and he leans on my arm, and I bow myself in the house of Rimmon, when I bow myself in the house of Rimmon, may the LORD pardon your servant in this matter.'
verses.comment: Retained repetition for emphasis in original.

verses.text: So Elisha said to him, 'Go in peace.' And he departed from Elisha a short distance.
verses.comment: 'short distance' matches Hebrew construction.

verses.text: But Gehazi, the servant of Elisha the man of God, said to himself, 'See, my master has spared Naaman this Aramean, by not accepting from him what he brought. As surely as the LORD lives, I will run after him and get something from him.'
So Gehazi chased after Naaman. When Naaman saw someone running after him, he got down from the chariot to meet him and said, 'Is everything all right?'
verses.comment: 'Is everything all right?' is literal for 'Is it peace?'

verses.text: And Gehazi said, 'Everything is all right. My master has sent me, saying,
verses.comment: Gehazi lies; translation preserves original words.

verses.text: Naaman said, 'Please, take two talents.' And he urged him, and bound two talents of silver in two bags, with two changes of clothes, and gave them to two of his servants, and they carried them ahead of Gehazi.
verses.comment: Silver weight kept literal; talents as above.

verses.text: When he came to the hill, Gehazi took the gifts from their hands and put them in the house, then sent the men away, and they left.
verses.comment: Kept action sequence literal.

verses.text: Then he went in and stood before his master. And Elisha said to him, 'Where have you come from, Gehazi?' He replied, 'Your servant did not go anywhere.'

But he said to him, 'Was my heart not with you when the man turned from his chariot to meet you? Is it a time to receive money and clothes, olive groves and vineyards, sheep and cattle, male and female servants?'
verses.comment: Elisha lists things Gehazi intended to acquire; closely rendered from Hebrew.

verses.text: Therefore, Naaman’s leprosy will cling to you and to your descendants forever.' And Gehazi went out from Elisha’s presence, leprous as white as snow.
verses.comment: Final curse and description as in Hebrew; 'white as snow' preserved.
